PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The PPTA will review and assess the performance of the LSE subsector in Viet Nam, in 
particular  schooling  for  ethnic  minority  and  other  disadvantaged  groups  and  identify  the 
challenges which are a bottleneck of socio-economic growth. The PPTA will help develop an 
investment  project  suitable  for  ADB  financing  in  terms  of  technical,  financial,  economic, 
institutional, and safeguard dimensions.  
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The PPTA aims that ADB will agree with the Government of Viet Nam on a project 
design that will help improve the employability and competitiveness of a young labor force of the 
country by 2020 through preparation of the feasibility study report of the project.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
4.  The TA is estimated to cost $888,800 equivalent, of which $800,000 equivalent will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV).  The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of cash contribution including office 
accommodation and transport, remuneration of per diem of counterpart staff and others.

D.  Consulting Services 
6.  ADB  will  finance  60  person-months  (pm)  of  consulting  services  including                         
(i) 6 international consultants totaling 23 pm; and (ii) 6 national consultants totaling 37 pm for 
the TA. An international firm will be engaged to provide a team of international and national 
consultants in accordance with Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by ADB and its Borrowers 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The selection and engagement of the international 
consulting firm will be done through quality- and cost-based selection (QCBS) using simplified 
technical proposal. The QCBS weighting will follow the standard quality-cost ratio of 80:20. 
Consulting services are summarized at Table A4.3 below, and the outline terms of reference for 
the project preparatory TA consultants are described in paragraphs 5 to 11.

7.  Ethnic  Minority  Education  Quality  Improvement  Specialists/Team  Leader 
(international–9pm,  national–12pm).  The  ethnic  minority  education  quality  improvement 
specialists/team leader will be responsible for the following tasks, but not limited to (i) coordinate 
ADB, PMU and consultants; (ii) analyze educational data by areas and propose strategies for 
quality improvement of LSE for disadvantaged groups; (iii) identify challenges and constraints in 
LSE  Equivalency  Program;  (iv)  develop  various  RRP  documents  including  donor  matrix, 
implementation  schedule,  staff  development  plan,  organizational  chart;  stakeholder 
consultations;  capacity  development  plan  for  the  executing  agency  (EA);  (v)  develop 
recommendation for appropriate loan covenants for compliance; (vi) help the PMU to organize 
the necessary PPTA workshops; and (vii) prepare the consultant reports in formats satisfactory 
to ADB and the Government (Inception report, draft interim report, interim report, draft TA final 
report, TA final report, draft and final project detailed outline and feasibility studies.  
 
8.  Education Material  and  Equipment  Specialists  (international–4pm, national–6pm). 
The specialist’s tasks will include the following, but not limited to (i) reviewing the existing 
instructional  materials  and  equipment  in  beneficiary  LSS  and  assess  the  needs  of 
additional/new materials and equipment; (ii) conducting the survey of designing, piloting and 
developing the bilingual instructional materials and teachers’ guides based on the new teacher 
training programs; (iii) proposing and piloting with NPIU/PPIU the effective teaching methods in 
the  multi-lingual  teaching  and  learning  environment;  and  (iv)  assisting  NPIU  and  the 
procurement specialists in developing the lists of equipment for the science laboratories and 
books for the libraries for the newly constructed schools. 
 
9.  Education Facilities and Procurement Specialist (international–5pm, national–8pm). 
The specialists’ tasks will include the following, but not limited to (i) assess the demands on the 
classroom to achieve the target enrollment rate for the beneficiary districts; (ii) review the 
geographical conditions for different target regions and propose type of classrooms matching 
each area; (iii) prepare procurement plan and procurement capacity assessment of the EA in 
accordance with ADB Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time); (iv) 
develop the implementation schedule of all activities of the proposed loan; (v) collect data and 
analyze cost norms for civil works and equipment procurement; and (vi) assess the procurement 
risk and prepare the risk assessment and risk mitigation plan.  
 
10.  Education  Economist/Financial  Analyst  (international–2pm,  national–4pm).  The 
specialist’s  tasks  will  include  the  following,  but  not  limited  to  (i)  review  the  flow  of  funds 
mechanisms, (ii) assess the requirements for financial system, (iii) assess the likelihood that

4   
 
counterpart  funds  and/or  co-financing  will  be  available,  (iv)  undertake  the  economic  and 
financial analysis of the proposed project, (v) complete a projection of forward incremental 
recurrent costs and assess the impact of incremental recurrent costs on the budget of the 
Ministry of Education and Training (MOET), (vi) conduct the financial management assessment 
(FMA) for the relevant entities involved in Project implementation, and (vii) prepare summary 
and detailed cost tables for the Project.  
 
11.  Social Development and Gender Specialist (international–2pm, national–5pm). The 
specialists’ tasks will include the following, but not limited to: (i) prepare profiles of the project 
districts in terms of demographic trends and socio-economic conditions; (ii) undertake an initial 
poverty and social analysis and assess a prospective social impact of the proposed loan project 
in accordance with Guidelines for Incorporation of Social Dimensions in ADB Operations; (iii) 
develop procedures to assess and a gender action plan based on ADB’s Policy on Gender and 
Development for the Project if necessary; (iv) assess the number of indigenous people and their 
socioeconomic  status  using  ADB’s  checklist  and  Indigenous  People  Impact  Categorization 
Form, and develop a short indigenous people’s development plan based on ADB’s Policy on 
Indigenous People and on Gender and Development, if necessary; (v) ensuring that GEN 
project category threshold requirements are satisfied vis-à-vis current guidelines for Gender 
Mainstreaming Categories; and (vi) development of a draft C&P strategy and plan. 
 
12.  Resettlement Specialists (international–1pm, national–2pm). The specialists’ tasks will 
include the following, but not limited to: (i) screen all sites identified for civil works to ensure that 
none  of  these  sites  will  entail  involuntary  resettlement  as  defined  in  ADB’s  Involuntary 
Resettlement Policy and operations manual section F1/operational procedures (OMF1/OP) on 
involuntary resettlement; (ii) develop a resettlement plan in accordance with ADB’s Involuntary 
Resettlement Policy and OMF1/OP if any of the sites for rehabilitation or expansion will result in 
involuntary resettlement; and (iii) assess land issues, titles, and the potential impact of the 
ensuing project. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  Project  Management and  Financial Management.  MOET  will  be  the  EA  and  will 
provide the counterpart support including a qualified TA project manager and project staff 
acceptable to ADB. The Project Management Unit (PMU) will be established in MOET. The 
equipment to be procured under the PPTA will be turned over to the EA upon the PPTA 
completion. TA Disbursements will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time). The Government was advised that 
approval of the TA does not commit ADB to financing any ensuing loan.
